subject: Re: [junit] Re: Can i do a assertion inside the setUp() method.
msgSnippet: ... The assertion in setUp() is of course executed, and the way that you have coded it guarantees a failure. However, you should NEVER put an assertion in
messageBody:
On Mon, 12 Jan 2004, [iso-8859-1] Karthikeyan D wrote:

> protected void setUp() {
> _collection = new ArrayList();
> _collection = null;
> assertNotNull("Collection null in my setupmethod
> ",_collection);
> }
...
> There were 2 failures:
> 1)
> testEmptyCollection(junit.samples.modelTest)junit.framework.AssertionFailedEr
> ror: Collection null in my setupmethod
> at junit.samples.modelTest.setUp(modelTest.java:17)
> 2)
> testOneItemCollection(junit.samples.modelTest)junit.framework.AssertionFailed
> Error: Collection null in my setupmethod
> at junit.samples.modelTest.setUp(modelTest.java:17)
>
> FAILURES!!!
> Tests run: 2, Failures: 2, Errors: 0
>
> Does the above mean that , the assertion in setUp() method is not
> considered as a test ? And also the test methods which does not have
> any code is also considered as failed . Any explanation for this. Or
> its not a advised practise to use assertion inside setup ?

The assertion in setUp() is of course executed, and the way that you have
coded it guarantees a failure.

However, you should NEVER put an assertion in setUp(). JUnit runs setUp()
before each of your test methods, the ones whose name begins with "test".
It is intended for use in setting up test fixtures, the set of objects
that the tests are run against.
